job_title: Alumni Relations Counselor in Longview, TX
pros: Being a student worker as a alumni caller is relatively straight forward an from time to time you hear some really amazing stories from the Alumni! Coworkers and immediate supervisors are pretty awesome as well.
cons: This job was great when I began, but got more and more vague as the year went on.  Let me elaborate.  The job was to call Alumni in the interest of keeping up with them, making sure they were still getting news about their Alma Mater, and asking if they wanted to donate to the scholarship fund (I can't remember for the life of me what it was called).  Initially it was all cut and dry, some people would want to talk and others wouldn't.  But the trouble began with the upper management changed and the money we were receiving started going "discretionary spending". After doing some digging, I determined that only 12% of all donations were going to scholarships, the other percent went to somewhere else, somewhere not in the university.  Specifically, not to the professors, the faculty/staff or to manage the campus.  I got fed up with this and finally began asking questions, it was at this point I was asked to keep quite and do my job (which included lying to curious Alumni).  It was at this point I had to quit the job for obvious ethical concerns.

job_title: Multiple Positions (Grader, Tutor, Student) in Longview, TX
pros: Safe work environment, Middle and lower management care about you, once you have a job you can usually keep it for as long as you want, most professors and staff care about the students and staff.
cons:
As a student you are sheltered from the school's internal politics but the longer you're there the more you notice.  Inconsistent enforcement of rules on students and staff. Who you know is very important and grudges are never forgotten. 
Huge turnover, I was an engineering student for 6 years and during that time 75% of Professors changed. A 5 year window of time will result in 70% staff turnover or higher. Many great staff members leave due to internal politics.
Huge variation in wages, some people make way more than they should while others are overdue for a raise.
Won't fire those that need to go.
Many people are fake, claim one thing and show one side while acting completely differently in a different situation. Hard to tell if people are being genuine.

The longer you're at LeTourneau the longer the list of cons becomes!

pros: I just read the reviews in chronological order and agreed with what was said.  Only the anonymous reviewers would tell the truth. Longview in general is full of pseudo-Christians who play the part for employment networking, so playing the same part when at work here is easy to do. I saw under Lunsford the change to compromising with a world view to get students. That made me sad, but, most churches are doing that these days as we fall into apostasy. All in all, I was there for the experience and that is what I got.  That is all employment at LETU will get you, and, the opportunity to make real friends.
cons: Low pay. No chance for advancement.  Management is typical - out for making an impression and making money.

job_title: Lead Flight Instructor in Longview, TX
pros: Hours are consistent.  New, techonologically advanced aircraft that are well maintained by a very professional maintenance department. Nice facilities. Some of the faculty are amazing to work with.
cons: Pay. You are paid similar to a waiter. Low base salary, and then given block pay for every 1.7 hours of billed time. They tell you to expect to work 40 hours a week, but in actuality, expect to work 50-60 hours a week, but receive compensation for around 20-30 hours of work. There is a lot of paperwork and scheduling can be a huge chunk of time, shuffling schedules and vying for airplanes.

review_title: A Stepping Stone To Anywhere Better
pros: There are two and they are actually big ones. In fact, they are big enough to keep some folks here for a decade, myself included. One is the free education afforded to you and family members. The other is that, in general, this is a 40 hour workweek kind of place. If family time is important to you, LETU is a reasonable place to be. They do very much value and respect family.
cons:
If you are looking for career advancement, this is not the place. Where you are is where you will be a year from now, 10 years from now. The only thing that seemingly changes is that the leadership are really good at adding more and more responsibility on you until you reach a point where you either leave or simply choose to exist, never really giving more than the bare minimum. 

Mediocrity is the sad result of a drastic lack of employee opportunity here. Staff pay is exceedingly low, even for this geographic area. Thanks to inflation, I make less today than I did 10 years ago when I started here. The few cost of living adjustments I've received in 10 years have not kept up with inflation. Morale among staff is typically pretty low. There is no reward for hard work. I've even heard it said by one executive leader here that "We have to be careful not to openly compliment people because we don't want to inadvertently praise some that don't deserve it."  

Faculty are worshipped as Gods and staff are treated as peasant serfs, though that may be a criticism of higher ed in general, but it's very true here. There is a strong good-ol-boy club here and if you happen to have been born with one too many X chromosomes, you will not likely find much respect.

If you like smallish town living, then Longview is a reasonably good place to live. It is big enough to have a mall and a selection of restaurants without any notion of real rush hour traffic. If you are used to a thriving metropolis though, Longview is hardly going to satisfy. It's also the third most violent city in the state of Texas (per capita.)
